qas.question: Czech's word order is flexible because it uses what to convey word function in a sentence?
In Czech an intransitive sentence may consist of only what?
What is encoded about a subject in verbs in Czech?
What is a hard to pronounce and remember term meaning primarily auxiliary verbs and pronouns?
Where must enclitics appear in a sentence?
What can an intransitive sentence consist only of in English?
Where is information about a sentence subject in English?
What is another word for word order?
Where must enclitics appear in an English sentence?
What appears before the enclitics in an English sentence?

context: Because Czech uses <a0_0>grammatical case<a0_0/> to convey word function in a sentence (instead of relying on word order, as English does), its word order is flexible. As a pro-drop language, in Czech an intransitive sentence can consist of only <a1_0><b5_0>a verb<b5_0/><a1_0/>; <a2_0>information<a2_0/> about its subject is <b6_0>encoded in the verb<b6_0/>. <a3_0><b7_0>Enclitics<b7_0/><a3_0/> (primarily auxiliary verbs and pronouns) must appear <b8_0>in the <a4_0>second syntactic slot<b8_0/><a4_0/> of a sentence, after <b9_0>the first stressed unit<b9_0/>. The first slot must contain a subject and object, a main form of a verb, an adverb or a conjunction (except for the light conjunctions a, "and", i, "and even" or ale, "but").
